ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Mattias, sorry to go overboard on the commentary but your ... I have a feeling starting minimally could still be made pretty cool.  The reason is that if

Subject: More on  Genetic Art using NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01


Hey Mattias, sorry to go overboard on the commentary but your 
project got me thinking.  You noted:

> 
> This program violates a few of the NEAT advantages;
>  * It doesn't use species (there'd be not point)
>  * It doesn't start minimally (that would be dull)
> 

I have a feeling starting minimally could still be made pretty 
cool.  The reason is that if you have some kind of vague shape or 
design in mind, you could kind of use the principle of 
complexification to get there.  In other words, you'd first start 
out with really simple base shapes and then as NEAT adds neurons 
progressively elaborate on them.  You could even let the user decide 
exactly when or how often to complexify.  You might even put a 
little number next to each picture representing network complexity.  
That way, a user can consciously protect innovation by giving a 
chance to more complex artists even if their pictures are initially 
a bit off from the simpler ones.  I think a program that lets you 
explore from the simple to the complex on your own could be made 
quite compelling.

ken
